sentences.sentence: I have mentioned that I had saved the few seeds of corn and rice, and I believe there were about thirty shoots of rice, and about twenty of corn.
Now I thought it a proper time to plant them after the rains, with the sun being in its southern position.
So I dug up a piece of ground, as well as I could, and dividing it into two parts, I planted my grain.
As I was planting, it came to me that I should not plant it all at first, because I did not know when was the proper time for it.
I planted about two-thirds of the seeds, leaving about a handful of( 一把… ) each.
It was a great comfort to me afterwards( 后来 ) that I did so, for not one grain of what I planted this time came to anything, because of the dry months following.
So I planted the rest of my seed in February, and this having the rainy months of March and April to water it, it gave a very good crop.
I found now that the seasons of the year might generally be divided, not into summer and winter, as in Europe, but into the rainy seasons and the dry seasons.
The rainy seasons lasted from late February to early April, and from late August to early October.
The dry seasons lasted from late April to early August, and late October to early February.
I sat inside as much as possible during the wet months.
Here I spent time talking to my parrot( 鹦鹉 ), and teaching him to speak.
I quickly taught him to know his own name, “Poll,” which was the first word I ever heard spoken in the island by any mouth but my own.
During this time I also tried many ways to make myself some baskets.
Though I did not finish them very well, I made them useful enough for my purpose.
In the months of November and December, I began expecting my crop of corn and rice.
And toward the end of December I harvested my corn.
My first crop was small, and I had no great difficulty to cut it down.
I harvested it in my way, for I cut nothing off but the ears( 穗 ), and carried it away in a great basket which I had made.
At the end of all my harvesting, I found I had almost two baskets of rice, and about two and a half baskets of corn.
I decided not to eat any of this crop, but to preserve it all for seed to be used the next season.
In the dry season, I worked at my next great task, of providing myself with corn and bread.
It might be truly said, that now I worked for my bread.
To begin with, I had no metal shovel( 铲子 ) to dig the earth, but only a wooden one.
This made my work harder, and not so well done. When the corn was being planted, I had no plow( 犁 ), but was forced to drag a heavy tree branch over the ground.
When the corn was growing, I wanted many things to fence it, secure it, harvest it, dry it, carry it home, and save it.
Then I wanted a stone to grind it, yeast( 酵母 ) and salt to make it into bread, and an oven( 炉子 ) to bake it.
First, I had no way to hold anything that was liquid, and not so much as a pot to boil anything.
However, considering the heat of the climate, I was sure that if I could find any clay, I might make some pots.
Once I dried them in the sun, they would no doubt be hard enough and strong enough to hold anything that was dry.
I decided to make some as large as I could, to hold what I wanted to put into them.
It would make the reader pity me, or rather laugh at me, to tell what ugly things I made.
I could only make two large ugly things—I cannot call them jars—in about two months’ work.
However, as the sun baked these two very dry and hard, I lifted them very gently up, and set them down again in two great baskets.
I packed them full of the rice and corn straw.
But what I most wanted was to get a pot to hold liquid, and cook on the fire.
It happened after some time, after cooking my meat in a pretty large fire, I found a broken piece of one of my pots in the coals.
It was burnt as hard as a stone, and red as a coal.
I said to myself, that certainly my pots might burn whole, if they would burn broken.
This set me to study how to set up my fire, so as to make it burn some pots.
I made three more pots, and placed my firewood( 柴火 ) all round them, till I saw the pots turn red-hot quite through.
When I saw them clear( 透明的 ) red, I let them stand in that heat about five or six hours.
Watching them all night, in the morning I had three very good pots, as hard burnt as anyone could want.
My next concern was to get a stone bowl to grind corn in.
After a great deal of time lost in searching for a suitably large stone, I gave up, and decided to use a big block of hard wood.
With the help of fire and much labor, I made a hollow( 凹陷的 ) place in it.
After this, I made a great heavy hammer of the wood called the iron-wood.
This I used to grind, or rather pound, my next crop of corn into flour for making bread.
The baking part was the next thing to be considered, since I had no oven( 炉子 ).
I made some bowls that were very broad, but not deep.
I burned these in the fire, and when I wanted to bake, I made a great fire.
When the firewood( 柴火 ) was burned pretty much into live( （煤炭等）燃烧着的 ) coals, I drew these forward upon some small stones, and there I let them lie, till the stones were very hot.
Then sweeping away all the coals, I put my loaves on the stones, and placed a pot upon them. Thus I baked my bread.
Thus I passed my second year.
My clothes had by now begun to rot( 腐烂 ).
Though it is true that the weather was so violently hot that there was no need for clothes, yet I could not go quite naked( 裸体的 ), for the sun frequently burned my skin.
I had begun to save the skins of all the creatures that I killed, and I had them hung up, and some of them were now dry enough to be useful.
These skins I used to make new clothes.
After this, I took a great deal of time and work to make an umbrella.
While I was doing all these things, I thought many times of the land which I had seen from the other side of the island.
I sometimes wished that I were on the other shore there, hoping that I might at last find some means of escape.
This set me thinking whether it was not possible to make myself a boat, like the boats that the natives of those climates make, out of the trunk of a tree.
I thought this might be possible, even easy.
I set to work to try and make one, despite my lack of tools.
At last with great time and effort I finished, having taken just under a year to build my boat.
My next plan was to take a sail around the island.
For this purpose, I put my boat in the water, with a sail made out of some of the pieces of my old ship’s sails.
I set my umbrella also in the front of the boat, to keep the heat of the sun off me.
Determined upon my trip, I set out in my fourth year on the island.
I found the voyage took much longer than I expected.
The island itself was not very large, yet I found a great strip( 狭长地带 ) of rocks lay out about six miles into the sea.
So I was forced to go a great way out to sea to go around( 避开 ) the rocks.
Suddenly I found myself in a great depth of water and a very fast current( 水流 ).
It hurried me farther and farther out from the shore, which was on my left hand side.
There was no wind blowing to help me, and I could do nothing to help myself. I began to give up hope.
Now I looked back upon my lonely island as the most pleasant place in the world, and all my heart could wish for was to be there again.
We never see our true situation, nor know how to value what we enjoy, until we one day discover that what we once had is gone.
